content:
Module Description Number of Parameters
Voice Encoder Initialized with the encoder parameters of the pre-trained SenseVoice-Large audio understanding model (An et al., 2024) ∼636similar-toabsent636\sim 636∼ 636M
Input Projector 2 Transformer layer and 1 CNN layer for dimensional transformation and perform 2x downsampling on the input ∼170similar-toabsent170\sim 170∼ 170M
Large Language Model Initialized with Qwen2.5-7B-instruct (Team, 2024) 7B
Output Projector Linear layer for dimensional transformation ∼6similar-toabsent6\sim 6∼ 6M
Voice Token LM Initialized with the LLM of the pre-trained CosyVoice2 (Du et al., 2024b) ∼370similar-toabsent370\sim 370∼ 370M
Full Duplex Predictor 1 Transformer layer and 1 linear-softmax output layer, both randomly initialized ∼18similar-toabsent18\sim 18∼ 18M
caption: Table 1: Descriptions of the modules in MinMo as depicted in Figure 3. MinMo has approximately 8 billion parameters in total.
description: Table 1 provides a detailed breakdown of the individual modules that constitute the MinMo model, which is depicted visually in Figure 3.  It lists each module's name, a concise description of its function within the overall architecture, and the approximate number of parameters it contains.  The table concludes by stating the total number of parameters in the MinMo model, which is approximately 8 billion.

content:
Category Specific Tasks Hours
Speech-to-Text Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) 630k
Speech-to-Text Translation (S2TT) 451k
Language Identification (LID) 34k
Contextual Bias Speech Recognition 50k
Speech Emotion Recognition (SER) 48k
Audio Event Detection (AED) 11k
Speaker Analysis 24k
Spoken Language Smoothing 0.4k
Speech-to-Text Chat 10k
Text-to-Speech Speech Synthesis 170k
Instruct Speech Synthesis 1k
Speech-to-Speech Speech-to-Speech chat 10k
Style-controllable Speech-to-Speech Chat 0.1k
Speech-to-ControlToken Full Duplex Interaction 4k
caption: Table 2: The multitask training data for MinMo. Task specifications can be found in Section 4.
description: Table 2 details the diverse dataset used to train MinMo, a multimodal large language model. It breaks down the training data across four categories: Speech-to-Text, Text-to-Speech, Speech-to-Speech, and Speech-to-ControlToken.  Each category lists multiple specific tasks (like Automatic Speech Recognition, Speech-to-Text Translation, Language Identification, etc.) and the number of hours of training data used for each.  This detailed breakdown provides insights into the scope and balance of training data used to achieve MinMo's capabilities.

content:
User: Please speaking very fast: Today is a happy day, full of laughter and joy.
Assistant: \faComment  (Fast speaking rate) Today is a happy day, full of laughter and joy.
User: Speaking with a tone of sadness: I miss my dear friend who moved away last month.
Assistant: \faComment  (Sad) I miss my dear friend who moved away last month.
caption: Table 3: Examples of text-to-speech data controlled by instructions.
description: This table presents examples of how user instructions, specifying various aspects of speech synthesis such as speed, emotion, and style, influence the generated audio output.  It demonstrates the MinMo model's capability to generate speech according to user-specified parameters, showcasing its instruction-following abilities for style-controllable speech synthesis.

caption: Table 4: Summary of evaluation benchmarks for MinMo in this report.
description: Table 4 provides a comprehensive overview of the evaluation benchmarks used to assess the performance of the MinMo model.  It details the specific tasks, datasets, and metrics employed in evaluating MinMo's capabilities across various aspects, including speech recognition and translation, speech analysis and understanding, speech-to-text enhancement, voice generation, and voice chat.  For each benchmark, the table indicates the type of task (e.g., multilingual speech recognition), the datasets used for evaluation (e.g., Aishell-2), and the metrics used to quantify performance (e.g., CER&WER). This table serves as a key reference for understanding the scope and methodology of the MinMo evaluation.

caption: Table 5: Multilingual speech recognition results from our MinMo and baseline models in terms of word error rate (WER) and character error rate (CER) on Mandarin, English, and multilingual public test sets. Results in parentheses are directly cited from papers. The best result for each test set is boldfaced.
description: This table presents a comparison of multilingual speech recognition performance between the MinMo model and several baseline models.  The metrics used are Word Error Rate (WER) for English and other languages, and Character Error Rate (CER) for Mandarin, Japanese, Korean, and Cantonese.  The table includes results on various publicly available datasets, including Aishell, LibriSpeech, Fleurs, and Common Voice, showcasing MinMo's performance with and without language identification (LID) information provided as part of the input.  Results from the baseline models are either reproduced using the same methodology or directly cited from the original papers.  The best performance for each test set is highlighted in bold.

caption: Table 6: Multilingual speech translation results from MinMo and baseline models on CoVoST2 and Fleurs test sets, in terms of BLEU score (higher is better). Results marked with † are obtained using translation prompts that specify the source language, rather than only indicating the target language. Results not reported in the original papers have been reproduced by the authors of this work.
description: This table compares the performance of MinMo against several baseline models on multilingual speech translation tasks, using the CoVoST2 and Fleurs datasets.  The performance is measured by BLEU score, a metric that assesses the quality of machine translation.  The table shows results for translations in various language pairs.  A distinction is made between results obtained using prompts that specify the source language and those that only specify the target language.  Note that some baseline results were reproduced by the authors because they weren't originally reported in the referenced papers.

description: This table presents a comparison of language identification accuracy achieved by MinMo and several other baseline models.  The evaluation was performed on the Fleurs dataset, which is a benchmark dataset encompassing 102 different languages.  The accuracy metric used is the percentage of correctly identified languages.

caption: Table 8: Statistics of the test sets for evaluating contextual biasing speech recognition. (hc denotes hard-case hotwords, which are hotwords with recall rates under 40% in basic speech recognition.
description: Table 8 presents the datasets used to evaluate the contextual biasing capability of MinMo's Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) system.  It details the number of utterances in each dataset, the proportion of utterances containing hotwords, and the number of hard-case hotwords (those with recall rates below 40% in standard ASR).  The datasets are categorized into 'Hotwords Biasing Test' and 'General Biasing Test' to assess performance under conditions with high and low densities of target hotwords, respectively. This allows for a thorough evaluation of MinMo's ability to accurately transcribe speech while accounting for the presence of specific keywords.

caption: Table 9: Performance of contextual biasing speech recognition from MinMo and the baseline model on the hotwords biasing test sets, in terms of character error rate (CER), recall of hotwords (R), and recall of hard-case hotwords (R-hc).
description: This table presents a comparison of the performance of MinMo and the baseline model, SeACo-Paraformer, on contextual biasing speech recognition tasks.  It uses three datasets designed to evaluate the ability of these models to correctly recognize speech containing specific hotwords. The metrics used for evaluation are Character Error Rate (CER), the overall recall rate of hotwords (R), and the recall rate specifically for "hard-case" hotwords (R-hc), which are defined as hotwords with a recall rate below 40% in standard speech recognition.  This allows for a nuanced analysis of how well each model handles this specialized speech recognition task.

caption: Table 10: Performance of contextual biasing speech recognition from MinMo on the general biasing test sets, in terms of character error rate (CER), precision (P), and recall (R).
description: This table presents the performance of MinMo, a multimodal large language model, on general contextual biasing speech recognition tasks.  It evaluates MinMo's ability to adapt to different contexts by incorporating specific hotwords or phrases into the input. The results are presented in terms of Character Error Rate (CER), Precision (P), and Recall (R). Lower CER indicates better performance, while higher Precision and Recall are desirable.

caption: Table 11: Speech emotion recognition performance from MinMo and the baseline models on various evaluation benchmarks, in terms of unweighted average accuracy (UA), weighted average accuracy (WA), and macro F1 score (F1). Results for SALMONN and Qwen-Audio are reproduced by the authors of this work.
description: This table presents a comparison of speech emotion recognition performance across multiple datasets and models.  The models compared include MinMo (the model introduced in the paper), SALMONN, and Qwen-Audio, alongside results from EmoBox (a speech emotion recognition toolkit).  Performance is evaluated using three metrics: unweighted average accuracy (UA), weighted average accuracy (WA), and macro F1 score (F1), offering a comprehensive view of each model's ability to correctly classify emotions in speech. Note that the results for SALMONN and Qwen-Audio are replicated from existing research by the paper's authors for consistent comparison.

caption: Table 12: Performance comparison between MinMo and the baseline models on the AIR-Bench benchmark, including Language ID, Gender, Age, Emotion, Vocal Sound, and Sound Question classification tasks, in terms of Accuracy. Results of Qwen-Audio and Qwen-Audio-Turbo (Chu et al., 2023), Pandagpt (Su et al., 2023), SALMONN (Tang et al., 2024) and Next-gpt (Wu et al., 2024) are cited from the official AIR-Bench website.
description: Table 12 presents a comparative analysis of MinMo's performance against several baseline models on the AIR-Bench benchmark.  The benchmark evaluates models across six speech and audio classification tasks: Language Identification, Gender recognition, Age estimation, Emotion recognition, Vocal Sound classification, and Sound Question Answering.  The table displays the accuracy achieved by each model on each task, providing a comprehensive overview of MinMo's capabilities relative to existing state-of-the-art models. The accuracy results for the comparison models (Qwen-Audio, Qwen-Audio-Turbo, Pandagpt, SALMONN, and Next-gpt) are sourced from the official AIR-Bench website.

The performance metrics used are unweighted average accuracy (UA), weighted average accuracy (WA), and macro F1 score (F1). This allows for a comprehensive assessment of MinMo's SER capabilities across diverse conditions.

description: This table presents examples of spoken language smoothing using the MinMo model.  It shows the original ASR transcript (Source) and MinMo's refined output (Target) for several sentences, demonstrating the model's ability to convert informal spoken language into more formal written text. The examples are taken from the SWAB test set, a dataset created for evaluating spoken language smoothing.

caption: Table 15: Spoken language smoothing performance of MinMo and Qwen2.5-7B on the SWAB test set, in terms of objective metrics (CER, BLEU, ROUGE-L, and BLEURT)
description: This table presents a quantitative comparison of MinMo and Qwen2.5-7B models' performance on the Spoken Language Smoothing task using the SWAB test set.  The evaluation includes objective metrics commonly used in evaluating the quality of text generation: Character Error Rate (CER), Bilingual Evaluation Understudy score (BLEU), ROUGE-L (recall-oriented understanding for gisting evaluation), and BLEURT (Bilingual Evaluation Understudy score). Lower CER indicates better accuracy, while higher BLEU, ROUGE-L, and BLEURT scores reflect better fluency and semantic similarity to human-generated text.

caption: Table 16: GPT-4 Turbo ranking scores of punctuation insertion and ITN for MinMo and the baseline models on the Chinese and English subsets of the Fleurs dataset.
description: This table presents a comparative analysis of punctuation insertion and inverse text normalization (ITN) performance using GPT-4 Turbo for scoring.  It compares the results of MinMo against two baseline models, SenseVoice-L and Whisper-large-v3, on both Chinese and English subsets of the Fleurs dataset.  The scores reflect the subjective quality of the models' output in terms of punctuation and ITN accuracy.

caption: Table 17: Performance comparison of content consistency (CER/WER) and objective speech quality (NMOS) between MinMo and the TTS baseline CosyVoice 2.0-SFT on the text-to-speech Chinese (zh) and English (en) test sets.
description: Table 17 presents a comparison of the performance of MinMo's voice decoder against the CosyVoice 2.0-SFT TTS baseline.  The comparison is made across two metrics: content consistency (measured by Character Error Rate (CER) for Chinese and Word Error Rate (WER) for English) and objective speech quality (measured by the Naturalness Mean Opinion Score (NMOS)). The results are shown separately for Chinese and English text-to-speech test sets, providing a comprehensive evaluation of MinMo's voice generation capabilities.

description: This table presents a comparison of instruction-following voice generation performance between the MinMo model and the baseline GLM-4-Voice model.  The comparison is based on a multi-turn speech-to-speech Chinese test set. The table shows the accuracy of both models in generating speech that adheres to various instructions such as specifying emotions, dialects, speaking rates, and role-playing.

caption: Table 19: Comparison of Spoken Question Answering Performance: Results for Moshi, GLM-4-Voice, and Freeze-Omni are sourced from their respective papers. S2T refers to the Speech-to-Text evaluation, while S2S denotes the Speech-to-Speech evaluation. The metric used for these assessments is accuracy. The TriviaQA∗ dataset does not provide a public test set, so the numerical results are not directly comparable and should be considered for reference only.
description: This table compares the performance of MinMo against three other models (Moshi, GLM-4-Voice, and Freeze-Omni) on three spoken question answering datasets (Llama Questions, TriviaQA, and Web Questions).  The comparison is done separately for speech-to-text (S2T) and speech-to-speech (S2S) tasks, using accuracy as the evaluation metric.  It's important to note that the TriviaQA dataset lacks a publicly available test set, so its results are not directly comparable to the other datasets and should only be considered for general comparison and reference.

caption: Table 20: Performance of MinMo in two in-house multi-turn speech-to-speech test sets: the Alpaca test set and the ChitChat test set. The Alpaca test set focuses on assessing logical reasoning capabilities, while the ChitChat test set is designed to evaluate casual conversational scenarios. For scoring, we utilized the Qwen-Max model.
description: This table presents the performance of the MinMo model on two internal multi-turn speech-to-speech datasets: Alpaca and ChitChat.  The Alpaca dataset assesses the model's logical reasoning abilities, while the ChitChat dataset evaluates its performance in casual conversations.  Scores were generated using the Qwen-Max model.
